div1.p: Pinto

Adjutant General's
OFFICE.
OCT 25 1900
ROLLS DIVISION.
[unclear]
RECD. OCT 24 1900

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 175 A 1900

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 183. }

HEADQUARTERS DIVISION OF CUBA,
Havana, October 17, 1900.

1. Major James B. Hickey, Assistant Adjutant General,
U. S. Volunteers, will proceed to Puerto Prícipe, Cuba,
and make an inspection of the post and troops thereat, and
upon completion thereof he will return to his proper
station, Havana, Cuba.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

2. Private William B. Baker, troop B, 2d Cavalry, hav-
ing been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Hamilton Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of desertion,
in violation of the 47th Article of War, was sentenced
“To be dishonorably discharged the service of the United States,
forfeiting all pay and allowances due him, and to be confined at
hard labor at such place as the reviewing authority may designate
for eighteen (18) months.”

The sentence is confirmed to date October 16, 1900, and
will be duly executed. Fort Columbus, New York Harbor,
is designated as the place of confinement, to which point
the prisoner will be sent upon further orders from these
Headquarters.

3. The leave of absence for one (1) month granted to
Acting Assistant Surgeon A. S. Pinto, U. S. Army, in
Special Orders No. 59, current series, Department of
Western Cuba, is hereby extended ten (10) days.

4. Private Raymond B. Heiser, Troop B, 2d Cavalry,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened
at Hamilton Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of desertion,
in violation of the 47th Article of War, evidence of one (1)
previous conviction having been considered by the court,
was sentenced “To be dishonorably discharged the service of the
United States, forfeiting all pay and allowances due him, and to
be confined at hard labor at such place as the reviewing authority
may direct for the period of two and one half (21/2) years.”

The sentence is confirmed to date October 16, 1900, and
will be duly executed. Fort Columbus, New York Harbor,
is designated as the place of confinement, to which point
the prisoner will be sent upon further orders from these
Headquarters.

5. Private George Lang, Troop B, 2d Cavalry, having
been tried by a general court-martial convened at Hamilton
Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of allowing a prisoner to
become drunk, in violation of the 62d Article of War, evi-
dence of four (4) previous convictions having been consid-
ered by the court, was sentenced “To be confined at hard
labor, under charge of the post guard, for two (2) months and to
forfeit ten (10) dollars per month for the same period.”

In the foregoing case of private George Lang, Troop B,
2d Cavalry, the proceedings, findings and sentence are ap-
proved. On account of the length of time that the prisoner
has been in confinement, so much of the sentence as relates
to confinement at hard labor is mitigated to confinement at
hard labor under the charge of the post guard for one
month. As thus mitigated the sentence is confirmed to
date October 16, 1900, and will be duly executed at the
post where his troop is stationed.

6. Private James E. Mullen, battery H, 2d Artillery, hav-
ing been tried by a general court-martial convened at Santa
Clara Battery, Havana, Cuba, and found guilty of absence
without leave, in violation of the 32d Article of War, and
conduct to the prejudice of good order and military disci-
pline in violation of the 62d Article of War, evidence of
four (4) previous convictions having been considered by
the court, was sentenced “To forfeit ten (10) dollars per month
for four (4) months.”

The sentence is confirmed to date October 16, 1900, and
will be duly executed. Private Mullen will be released from
confinement and restored to duty with his battery.
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:

H. L. SCOTT,
Adjutant General.
